title: Germany's far-right AfD wins landmark first regional vote in Thuringia exit poll
summary: The far-right Alternative for Germany took between 30.5 and 33.5% of the vote in Thuringia, according to exit polls, with the conservative CDU in second place at around 24.5%.

title: Israel union calls for general strike in support of Gaza hostage deal, tens of thousands hit the streets
summary: The bodies of six hostages were recovered from a tunnel in Gaza on Saturday, one of them an Israel-American dual national. Israeli health ministry spokeswoman Shira Solomon said the hostages were 'murdered by Hamas terrorists with several close-range gunshots,' some 48-72 hours before their autopsies.

title: 'For Macron, appointing Cazeneuve as prime minister would have a political and personal cost'
summary: Emmanuel Macron and former Socialist prime minister Bernard Cazeneuve will meet on Monday morning at the Elysée as part of the French president's consultations on appointing a new prime minister. Le Monde's political columnist Solenn de Royer looks back at their close relationship.

title: Mbappé scores first La Liga goal for Real Madrid: 'Great moment'
summary: Kylian Mbappé has been facing pressure after a string of goalless matches, prompting criticism from the Spanish press, but coach Carlo Ancelotti hit back on Saturday, insisting that his star recruit was settling in well.

title: Child hunger reaches unprecedented levels in Gaza
summary: Unlike the children who died in the bombardments, there is no official count of those who died of malnutrition or dehydration. However, doctors are reporting a growing number of very young victims.

title: Why women's working hours in Germany are still hindering the country's growth
summary: With 55% of German women in part-time work, the government wants to unlock what it sees as untapped potential. But there are still many barriers in West Germany, an East-West divide that is becoming political.

title: Gao Zhen, a prominent contemporary artist, arrested in China
summary: Gao Zhen, who works alongside his brother Gao Qiang and has devoted most of his work to condemning Maoism and the crimes of the regime, has been held under a law against attacking the reputation and honor of national heroes and martyrs.

title: Mayan forest concessions in Guatemala: A model for combating deforestation
summary: In the north of the country, vast tracts of tropical forest are protected by local populations who practice sustainable forestry. It's a model that could be more widely used.

title: Telegram chief Pavel Durov's whirlwind week
summary: Arrested on August 24 on his arrival at Le Bourget airport, the Telegram founder was placed under judicial supervision with a ban on leaving the country. Le Monde looks back at a week that made headlines around the world.

title: Cancers becoming increasingly common among young people in the US
summary: A major American study has determined that generations born in the 1980s and 1990s are more likely to develop cancer than their elders. However, these findings are not solely due to an aging population, but sometimes due to earlier diagnoses.

title: Paralympic organizers postpone triathlon in Seine over water quality
summary: All the Paralympic para-triathlon events scheduled to take place in Paris on September 1 have been postponed by one day.

title: South Korea's battle of the sexes in full swing
summary: Tensions between men and women are on the rise in South Korean society. Advances in women's rights and a rejection of traditional hierarchies are facing resistance from a 'masculinist' fringe with varying degrees of support right up to the top echelons of the government.

title: 'The mistake made by the parties that prospered in West Germany for decades was to believe that they could import their model, unchanged, to the former East'
summary: As regional elections in Thuringia and Saxony get underway on Sunday, author Steffen Mau examines the rise of the far right in the former GDR.

title: Climate: Kazakhstan's Caspian Sea is retreating
summary: The level of the world's largest inland sea has been falling steadily since 2006. Kazakh authorities are increasingly concerned about its drying up.

title: Donald Trump was in the desert. Does anyone care?
summary: Destabilized by the momentum around Kamala Harris, Donald Trump is struggling to regain control. The day before a rally in Arizona on August 22, the former US president visited the border between the US and Mexico to talk immigration.

title: The origins of Bangladesh's student protest
summary: Two of the leaders of the movement that led to the fall of Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina have joined the interim government set up by economist Muhammad Yunus.

title: In Los Angeles, the Château Marmont, refuge for fallen angels
summary: This summer, 'M' passes through the doors of some of film's legendary hotels. In 2010, Sofia Coppola set up her cameras at the Chateau Marmont to shoot 'Somewhere,' a reflection of a certain Hollywood melancholy.

title: Brazil's Federal Supreme Court escalates tensions with Musk after suspending X
summary: Judge Alexandre de Moraes, who is in charge of the main investigations into former president Jair Bolsonaro, ordered the platform to delete certain accounts and accused it of facilitating the spread of fake news. Musk denounced the move as an obstacle to 'free speech.'

title: Captain Paul Watson continues anti-whaling fight from behind bars: 'Best prison I've been in'
summary: The 73-year-old activist said he has been signing autographs while detained at Greenland's Nuuk Prison, where he can watch as whales and icebergs pass by his window.

title: 'French people, make more of an effort not to become Europeans!'
summary: As the political crisis simmers in France, French academic Pascal Ory sings the praises of Switzerland, a leaderless country that practices both participatory democracy and compromise.

title: Vacations, state visits, honeymoons – When Vladimir Putin once strolled through Ukraine
summary: Up until the annexation of Crimea in 2014, the Russian president made frequent visits to his Ukrainian neighbor. From Kyiv to Kharkiv, via the Carpathians, Zaporizhzhia and Mykolaiv, the head of the Kremlin projected his imperialist obsession with a 'New Russia' onto the very cities he is now bombarding.

title: Macron hosts predecessors and prime minister hopefuls
summary: Former presidents Nicolas Sarkozy and François Hollande are to meet with Emmanuel Macron, as well as former Socialist prime minister Bernard Cazeneuve and conservative former minister Xavier Bertrand, seen as the frontrunners to become the new prime minister.

title: Bison are back in Europe, a century after they were driven to extinction
summary: 'Repairing the Earth' (1/6). Some 180 herbivores live in the Tarcu mountains in south-west Romania. The reintroduction of the continent's largest land mammal is one of conservation's success stories.

title: South Korea opens probe into Telegram for deepfake porn
summary: Following public outcry over cases involving AI-generated porn, including depictions of teenagers, South Korea has launched an investigation into the encrypted messaging platform for 'abetting' the crimes.

title: Regional elections in Germany: far right in the lead, Olaf Scholz's coalition even more fragile
summary: The AfD party came out on top in Thuringia, a first for a German far-right party since WWII, and was a close second in Saxony. Chancellor Olaf Scholz's SPD dropped, while his Green and Liberal Democrat allies collapsed. It is a serious setback for Scholz one year before the general elections.

title: 2024 Paralympics: Valentina Petrillo, a pioneer for transgender athletes
summary: The 50-year-old visually impaired Italian sprinter will race in the 400 m, in the T12 category, on September 2. Whatever her result, she sees her participation in the event as a 'real victory.'

title: Anger and shock rock Israel after discovery of six dead hostages in Gaza Strip tunnels
summary: Some of the hostages' families accuse Benjamin Netanyahu's government of undermining any possibility of an agreement with Hamas, and therefore the release of the hostages still being held.

title: Netherlands' Plat retains title in delayed Paralympics triathlon
summary: The 33-year-old Dutchman finished in a time of 58min 16sec to claim his third Paralympic title in a row after victory at Rio 2016 and Tokyo 2020.

title: Trial opens for man accused of drugging wife and letting 51 men rape her
summary: Dominique P., a 71-year-old pensioner, who let his wife be raped by men he found on the Internet, will be tried over four months in a French criminal court alongside the alleged rapists.

title: Partial strike in Israel over Gaza hostages
summary: The Histadrut trade union called a nationwide strike beginning at 6 am local time, a day after mass demonstrations following the army's announcement that troops had recovered the bodies of six hostages 'murdered' in a Gaza tunnel.

title: Oasis fans' outcry spurs British government to probe dynamic pricing
summary: After fans of the Britpop band were confronted with hugely inflated prices for tickets for the 14-date tour, the British government has announced a probe into the 'transparency and use' of dynamic or surge pricing.

title: Lawyer Henri Leclerc, a staunch defender of civil liberties, has died
summary: The prominent Paris lawyer, known for representing journalists, politicians and the May 1968 leftists, and who served as president of the French Human Rights League, last argued a case in 2020. He died on August 31.

title: Sweden recommends no screens for toddlers
summary: As part of a series of public health recommendations for parents, the Swedish government has also recommended progressive limits on screen time, ranging from one to three hours per day for children from 2-18.

title: Macron considers new name in prime minister search
summary: Sources said the president was considering Thierry Beaudet, the head of the Economic, Social and Environmental Council. Le Monde has learned that the Elysée has already found a chief of staff for the next prime minister.

title: Israeli labor court orders end to strike pushing for Gaza hostage deal
summary: The Histadrut trade union called a nationwide strike after the bodies of six hostages were found, as protesters demanded a deal to secure the release of remaining captives.

title: German Chancellor Scholz calls on parties to isolate far right
summary: Following regional elections in the eastern states of Thuringia and Saxony, in which the far-right AfD party won over 30% of votes, politicians from both the right and left have called to exclude it from governing coalitions.

title: Eiffel descendants criticize plan to keep Olympic rings on tower
summary: 'The Eiffel Tower should not become an advertising outpost,' said a great-great-grandson of the tower's designer Gustave Eiffel. Opponents to Paris Mayor Anne Hidalgo have also attacked her decision.

title: War in Ukraine: Kharkiv hit by hail of missiles in retaliation for Kyiv's attacks on Russia
summary: After six weeks of calm, Ukraine's second-largest city was once again the target of massive bombardments. Six people died on Friday and 47 others were wounded on Sunday, on the eve of the start of the new school year.

title: Paris 2024 Paralympics: In blind football, silence is golden
summary: In their first group match, the French team beat China (1-0), the second-placed team in the world. The fans switched between moments of silence during the game's periods and jubilation outside of them.

title: War in Ukraine: Circumstances surrounding destruction of F-16 remain unclear
summary: Air Force Commander Mykola Oleshchuk was fired on Friday by President Volodymyr Zelensky, following the loss of an American-made fighter jet and the death of its pilot.

title: Historic French church ravaged by fire
summary: Early in the morning on Monday, September 2, a fire broke out in the 19th-century church in the northern French town of Saint-Omer. No-one was hurt, but the church's steeple has collapsed.

title: Vladimir Putin's visit to Mongolia embarrasses the country
summary: Mongolia is the first International Criminal Court member state to be visited by the Russian president since the court issued an arrest warrant for him in 2023.

title: Mpox: French health authorities recommend booster shot to combat risk of new outbreak
summary: The National Authority for Health is calling on sex workers and men who have sex with men to be vaccinated against the disease, in view of the intense circulation of the monkeypox virus in Africa.

title: Biden says Netanyahu not doing enough to get hostage deal
summary: Speaking before an important meeting with hostage negotiators on Monday, the US president said they were 'very close' to a final proposal to present to Israel  and Hamas.

title: UK announces suspension of some arms sales to Israel
summary: The government announced on Monday it found a "clear risk" that UK arms may be used in serious violation of humanitarian law relating to the treatment of Palestinian detainees and the supply of aid to Gaza.

title: Pope Francis sets off for Indonesia at start of longest tour as pontiff
summary: Francis will arrive in Jakarta on Tuesday to begin a four-nation tour that is also his farthest.

title: US seizes Venezuela leader Maduro's plane in Dominican Republic
summary: The US Justice Department said the jet was 'illegally purchased' and flew it to Florida on Monday.

title: Horrified by murder of six Israeli hostages, US refuses to admit its strategy has hit an impasse
summary: While working, unsuccessfully, for a ceasefire in Gaza, the Biden administration has maintained its support for Israel. Kamala Harris has shown herself to be more concerned about the plight of the Palestinians, but she does not want to expose herself to accusations of turning her back on the US ally.

title: US hotel workers on strike: Hospitality work is 'undervalued', 'disproportionately women and people of color doing the work'
summary: The UNITE HERE union said a total of 15,000 workers, who demand higher pay, fairer workloads and the reversal of Covid-era cuts, have voted to authorize strikes, which could soon spread to other cities.

title: US Open: Jessica Pegula reaches her 7th Grand Slam quarterfinal
summary: In the men's tournament, No. 5 Daniil Medvedev, the 2021 champion will face No. 1 Jannik Sinner or No. 14 Tommy Paul in the quarterfinals.

title: 'In economic matters, as in the Olympics, we celebrate the coming together of peoples and continents, but we exacerbate nationalist sentiments'
summary: After Spain's government blocked the takeover of the local rail champion, Le Monde columnist Philippe Escande explains that whether social, economic, or political, there are many obstacles to doux commerce.
